Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_species: South of Beardmore Glacier BOLD:AAF 7379               L ASUB-002 (4)* : > Antarcticinella monoculata, SVL .
Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: South of Beardmore Glacier BOLD:AAF 7379               L ASUB-002 (4)* : > Antarcticinella monoculata, SVL .
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: South of Beardmore Glacier BOLD:AAF 7379               L ASUB-002 (4)* : > Antarcticinella monoculata, SVL .
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: South of Beardmore Glacier BOLD:AAF 7379               L ASUB-002 (4)* : > Antarcticinella monoculata, SVL .
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: South of Beardmore Glacier BOLD:AAF 7379               L ASUB-002 (4)* : > Antarcticinella monoculata, SVL .
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: South of Beardmore Glacier BOLD:AAF 7379               L ASUB-002 (4)* : > Antarcticinella monoculata, SVL .
Sentence_location: Their long-term persistence in Antarctica would have necessitated survival in local refugia during glacial maxima followed by recolonization during more favorable interglacial periods (14).

Sentence_species: South of Beardmore Glacier BOLD:AAF 7379               L ASUB-002 (4)* : > Antarcticinella monoculata, SVL .
Sentence_location: Our genetic data corroborate climate reconstructions and estimates of past warm periods of reduced ice and absent ice shelf in the Ross Sea region, during which time open seaways would have facilitated dispersal of Collembola, and possibly other taxa.

Sentence_species: South of Beardmore Glacier BOLD:AAF 7379               L ASUB-002 (4)* : > Antarcticinella monoculata, SVL .
Sentence_location: For example, ancient and vicariant species of Antarctic Peninsula and Scotia Arc endemic midges have been separated for an estimated 49 My, since before the opening of the Drake Passage between South America and the South Shetland Islands 33 Mya to 30 Mya (21).

Sentence_species: South of Beardmore Glacier BOLD:AAF 7379               L ASUB-002 (4)* : > Antarcticinella monoculata, SVL .
Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_location: Long-range dispersal of Collembola, particularly in the vicinity of the Ross Ice Shelf (Ross Sea region), would have only been possible with access to liquid water during periods of glacial retreat, as survival under shelf ice is extremely unlikely.

Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_location: Their long-term persistence in Antarctica would have necessitated survival in local refugia during glacial maxima followed by recolonization during more favorable interglacial periods (14).

Sentence_location: Our genetic data corroborate climate reconstructions and estimates of past warm periods of reduced ice and absent ice shelf in the Ross Sea region, during which time open seaways would have facilitated dispersal of Collembola, and possibly other taxa.

Sentence_location: For example, ancient and vicariant species of Antarctic Peninsula and Scotia Arc endemic midges have been separated for an estimated 49 My, since before the opening of the Drake Passage between South America and the South Shetland Islands 33 Mya to 30 Mya (21).

Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_location: Downloaded by guest on August 25, 2020 We assessed levels of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 (COI) sequence divergence for the six known species of Collembola found in southern Victoria Land (SVL), the Queen Alexandra Range (QAR), and the Queen Maud Mountains (QMM), within the Ross Sea region of continental Antarctica (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: BOLD:ACT2971 rypt nivicolus, SVL Entomobryomorpha: CNIV-006 (1) lsotomidae CNIV-013 (1) CNIV-008 (2) Mackay Glacier coastal CNIV-015 (1)* BOLD:AAG3913 CNIV-005 (16) CNIV-007 (1) 724 | CNIV-014 (2) drole Glaci owle Glacier \ ee -BOLD:ACS9977 99 |;CNIV-009/12 (2)* ENOL 3 Springtail Point CNIV-004 (5) BOLD:ADB9811 | CNIV-003 (1) Poduromorpha: Biscoia sudpolaris, QAR-QMM Hypogastruridae BSUD-001, DQ309568 (1) BSUD-002 (1) BSUD-003 (30)* BSUD-004 (1) BSUD-005 (2) Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni, SVL-QAR <{| GHOD-001 ( GHOD-071 ( Mount Gran, SVL, BOLD:ADC1091 GHOD-090 ( Gateway Ridge, QAR, BOLD:AAT9260 —= 076 (3 2 3)" - Towle Glacier, SVL Beardmore Glacier ‘ nN : BOLD:AAJ8383                        GHOD-089 (1) .
Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_location: We suggest that these biological data provide evidence to corroborate hypothesized local geological/glaciological events and enhance our understanding of terrestrial and glaciological landscape evolution in Antarctica.

Sentence_location: Discussion Past climatic and geological changes have constrained terrestrial invertebrate distributions in Antarctica, influencing the genetic structure of extant species (38).

Sentence_location: If these isolated populations are not highly abundant (e.g., only two individuals were found for the Mount Gran lineage of G. hodgson‘), they would be greatly affected by genetic drift and would therefore also be of special conservation concern.

Sentence_location: During this time when conditions were warmer, multiple collapses of the WAIS likely occurred (45, 46), lasting for extended periods, and this would have drastically improved dispersal opportunities for Collembola in the Ross Sea region, facilitated by flotation along coastal margins.

Sentence_location: For G. hodgsoni, warm periods 3.2 Mya to 2.7 Mya (52) may have provided dispersal opportunities for this species among SVL locations, after which the Mount Gran and Towle Glacier Table 1.

Sentence_location: The finer-scale genetic variation in G. hodgsoni among the widespread coastal populations (<1.6% divergence) could further be attributed to the most recent warm events within the last 2 My, as has been considered for three species of Collembola from the South Shetland Islands (53).

Sentence_location: Overall, our analyses suggest that the presence of an ice sheet in the Ross Sea is a formidable barrier to gene flow, preventing dispersal along coastal margins, and the extent and duration of ice expansion and contraction have been the primary driver in structuring the lineages of contemporary Antarctic Collembola.

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_species: BOLD:ACT2971 rypt nivicolus, SVL Entomobryomorpha: CNIV-006 (1) lsotomidae CNIV-013 (1) CNIV-008 (2) Mackay Glacier coastal CNIV-015 (1)* BOLD:AAG3913 CNIV-005 (16) CNIV-007 (1) 724 | CNIV-014 (2) drole Glaci owle Glacier \ ee -BOLD:ACS9977 99 |;CNIV-009/12 (2)* ENOL 3 Springtail Point CNIV-004 (5) BOLD:ADB9811 | CNIV-003 (1) Poduromorpha: Biscoia sudpolaris, QAR-QMM Hypogastruridae BSUD-001, DQ309568 (1) BSUD-002 (1) BSUD-003 (30)* BSUD-004 (1) BSUD-005 (2) Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni, SVL-QAR <{| GHOD-001 ( GHOD-071 ( Mount Gran, SVL, BOLD:ADC1091 GHOD-090 ( Gateway Ridge, QAR, BOLD:AAT9260 —= 076 (3 2 3)" - Towle Glacier, SVL Beardmore Glacier ‘ nN : BOLD:AAJ8383                        GHOD-089 (1) .
Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: BOLD:ACT2971 rypt nivicolus, SVL Entomobryomorpha: CNIV-006 (1) lsotomidae CNIV-013 (1) CNIV-008 (2) Mackay Glacier coastal CNIV-015 (1)* BOLD:AAG3913 CNIV-005 (16) CNIV-007 (1) 724 | CNIV-014 (2) drole Glaci owle Glacier \ ee -BOLD:ACS9977 99 |;CNIV-009/12 (2)* ENOL 3 Springtail Point CNIV-004 (5) BOLD:ADB9811 | CNIV-003 (1) Poduromorpha: Biscoia sudpolaris, QAR-QMM Hypogastruridae BSUD-001, DQ309568 (1) BSUD-002 (1) BSUD-003 (30)* BSUD-004 (1) BSUD-005 (2) Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni, SVL-QAR <{| GHOD-001 ( GHOD-071 ( Mount Gran, SVL, BOLD:ADC1091 GHOD-090 ( Gateway Ridge, QAR, BOLD:AAT9260 —= 076 (3 2 3)" - Towle Glacier, SVL Beardmore Glacier ‘ nN : BOLD:AAJ8383                        GHOD-089 (1) .
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: BOLD:ACT2971 rypt nivicolus, SVL Entomobryomorpha: CNIV-006 (1) lsotomidae CNIV-013 (1) CNIV-008 (2) Mackay Glacier coastal CNIV-015 (1)* BOLD:AAG3913 CNIV-005 (16) CNIV-007 (1) 724 | CNIV-014 (2) drole Glaci owle Glacier \ ee -BOLD:ACS9977 99 |;CNIV-009/12 (2)* ENOL 3 Springtail Point CNIV-004 (5) BOLD:ADB9811 | CNIV-003 (1) Poduromorpha: Biscoia sudpolaris, QAR-QMM Hypogastruridae BSUD-001, DQ309568 (1) BSUD-002 (1) BSUD-003 (30)* BSUD-004 (1) BSUD-005 (2) Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni, SVL-QAR <{| GHOD-001 ( GHOD-071 ( Mount Gran, SVL, BOLD:ADC1091 GHOD-090 ( Gateway Ridge, QAR, BOLD:AAT9260 —= 076 (3 2 3)" - Towle Glacier, SVL Beardmore Glacier ‘ nN : BOLD:AAJ8383                        GHOD-089 (1) .
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: BOLD:ACT2971 rypt nivicolus, SVL Entomobryomorpha: CNIV-006 (1) lsotomidae CNIV-013 (1) CNIV-008 (2) Mackay Glacier coastal CNIV-015 (1)* BOLD:AAG3913 CNIV-005 (16) CNIV-007 (1) 724 | CNIV-014 (2) drole Glaci owle Glacier \ ee -BOLD:ACS9977 99 |;CNIV-009/12 (2)* ENOL 3 Springtail Point CNIV-004 (5) BOLD:ADB9811 | CNIV-003 (1) Poduromorpha: Biscoia sudpolaris, QAR-QMM Hypogastruridae BSUD-001, DQ309568 (1) BSUD-002 (1) BSUD-003 (30)* BSUD-004 (1) BSUD-005 (2) Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni, SVL-QAR <{| GHOD-001 ( GHOD-071 ( Mount Gran, SVL, BOLD:ADC1091 GHOD-090 ( Gateway Ridge, QAR, BOLD:AAT9260 —= 076 (3 2 3)" - Towle Glacier, SVL Beardmore Glacier ‘ nN : BOLD:AAJ8383                        GHOD-089 (1) .
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_location: Their long-term persistence in Antarctica would have necessitated survival in local refugia during glacial maxima followed by recolonization during more favorable interglacial periods (14).

Sentence_species: BOLD:ACT2971 rypt nivicolus, SVL Entomobryomorpha: CNIV-006 (1) lsotomidae CNIV-013 (1) CNIV-008 (2) Mackay Glacier coastal CNIV-015 (1)* BOLD:AAG3913 CNIV-005 (16) CNIV-007 (1) 724 | CNIV-014 (2) drole Glaci owle Glacier \ ee -BOLD:ACS9977 99 |;CNIV-009/12 (2)* ENOL 3 Springtail Point CNIV-004 (5) BOLD:ADB9811 | CNIV-003 (1) Poduromorpha: Biscoia sudpolaris, QAR-QMM Hypogastruridae BSUD-001, DQ309568 (1) BSUD-002 (1) BSUD-003 (30)* BSUD-004 (1) BSUD-005 (2) Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni, SVL-QAR <{| GHOD-001 ( GHOD-071 ( Mount Gran, SVL, BOLD:ADC1091 GHOD-090 ( Gateway Ridge, QAR, BOLD:AAT9260 —= 076 (3 2 3)" - Towle Glacier, SVL Beardmore Glacier ‘ nN : BOLD:AAJ8383                        GHOD-089 (1) .
Sentence_location: Our genetic data corroborate climate reconstructions and estimates of past warm periods of reduced ice and absent ice shelf in the Ross Sea region, during which time open seaways would have facilitated dispersal of Collembola, and possibly other taxa.

Sentence_species: BOLD:ACT2971 rypt nivicolus, SVL Entomobryomorpha: CNIV-006 (1) lsotomidae CNIV-013 (1) CNIV-008 (2) Mackay Glacier coastal CNIV-015 (1)* BOLD:AAG3913 CNIV-005 (16) CNIV-007 (1) 724 | CNIV-014 (2) drole Glaci owle Glacier \ ee -BOLD:ACS9977 99 |;CNIV-009/12 (2)* ENOL 3 Springtail Point CNIV-004 (5) BOLD:ADB9811 | CNIV-003 (1) Poduromorpha: Biscoia sudpolaris, QAR-QMM Hypogastruridae BSUD-001, DQ309568 (1) BSUD-002 (1) BSUD-003 (30)* BSUD-004 (1) BSUD-005 (2) Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni, SVL-QAR <{| GHOD-001 ( GHOD-071 ( Mount Gran, SVL, BOLD:ADC1091 GHOD-090 ( Gateway Ridge, QAR, BOLD:AAT9260 —= 076 (3 2 3)" - Towle Glacier, SVL Beardmore Glacier ‘ nN : BOLD:AAJ8383                        GHOD-089 (1) .
Sentence_location: For example, ancient and vicariant species of Antarctic Peninsula and Scotia Arc endemic midges have been separated for an estimated 49 My, since before the opening of the Drake Passage between South America and the South Shetland Islands 33 Mya to 30 Mya (21).

Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_location: Long-range dispersal of Collembola, particularly in the vicinity of the Ross Ice Shelf (Ross Sea region), would have only been possible with access to liquid water during periods of glacial retreat, as survival under shelf ice is extremely unlikely.

Sentence_location: Downloaded by guest on August 25, 2020 We assessed levels of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 (COI) sequence divergence for the six known species of Collembola found in southern Victoria Land (SVL), the Queen Alexandra Range (QAR), and the Queen Maud Mountains (QMM), within the Ross Sea region of continental Antarctica (Fig. 1).

Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_location: Discussion Past climatic and geological changes have constrained terrestrial invertebrate distributions in Antarctica, influencing the genetic structure of extant species (38).

Sentence_location: If these isolated populations are not highly abundant (e.g., only two individuals were found for the Mount Gran lineage of G. hodgson‘), they would be greatly affected by genetic drift and would therefore also be of special conservation concern.

Sentence_location: During this time when conditions were warmer, multiple collapses of the WAIS likely occurred (45, 46), lasting for extended periods, and this would have drastically improved dispersal opportunities for Collembola in the Ross Sea region, facilitated by flotation along coastal margins.

Sentence_location: For G. hodgsoni, warm periods 3.2 Mya to 2.7 Mya (52) may have provided dispersal opportunities for this species among SVL locations, after which the Mount Gran and Towle Glacier Table 1.

Sentence_location: The finer-scale genetic variation in G. hodgsoni among the widespread coastal populations (<1.6% divergence) could further be attributed to the most recent warm events within the last 2 My, as has been considered for three species of Collembola from the South Shetland Islands (53).

Sentence_location: Overall, our analyses suggest that the presence of an ice sheet in the Ross Sea is a formidable barrier to gene flow, preventing dispersal along coastal margins, and the extent and duration of ice expansion and contraction have been the primary driver in structuring the lineages of contemporary Antarctic Collembola.

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_species: GHOD-075 (2) BOLD:ACT2851        Poduromorpha: Tullbergiidae   TMED-003 (1) TMED-002 (48)* TMED-001 (1) Shackleton Glacier © 7 BOLD:ADL3007 “ee   Symphypleona: Sminthuridae Sminthurus viridis (1), China, KJ155514 1% divergence Fig. 2.
Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: GHOD-075 (2) BOLD:ACT2851        Poduromorpha: Tullbergiidae   TMED-003 (1) TMED-002 (48)* TMED-001 (1) Shackleton Glacier © 7 BOLD:ADL3007 “ee   Symphypleona: Sminthuridae Sminthurus viridis (1), China, KJ155514 1% divergence Fig. 2.
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: GHOD-075 (2) BOLD:ACT2851        Poduromorpha: Tullbergiidae   TMED-003 (1) TMED-002 (48)* TMED-001 (1) Shackleton Glacier © 7 BOLD:ADL3007 “ee   Symphypleona: Sminthuridae Sminthurus viridis (1), China, KJ155514 1% divergence Fig. 2.
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: GHOD-075 (2) BOLD:ACT2851        Poduromorpha: Tullbergiidae   TMED-003 (1) TMED-002 (48)* TMED-001 (1) Shackleton Glacier © 7 BOLD:ADL3007 “ee   Symphypleona: Sminthuridae Sminthurus viridis (1), China, KJ155514 1% divergence Fig. 2.
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: High levels of genetic divergence have also been found across small spatial scales (<20 km) among mite populations on either side of sub-Antarctic Marion Island (42) as well as among continental Antarctic populations of Fnesea propria and Friesea gretae (previously known as Friesea grisea; ref. 43) in northern Victoria Land (36), attributed to historical events and geographical barriers preventing dispersal.
Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_species: High levels of genetic divergence have also been found across small spatial scales (<20 km) among mite populations on either side of sub-Antarctic Marion Island (42) as well as among continental Antarctic populations of Fnesea propria and Friesea gretae (previously known as Friesea grisea; ref. 43) in northern Victoria Land (36), attributed to historical events and geographical barriers preventing dispersal.
Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: High levels of genetic divergence have also been found across small spatial scales (<20 km) among mite populations on either side of sub-Antarctic Marion Island (42) as well as among continental Antarctic populations of Fnesea propria and Friesea gretae (previously known as Friesea grisea; ref. 43) in northern Victoria Land (36), attributed to historical events and geographical barriers preventing dispersal.
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: High levels of genetic divergence have also been found across small spatial scales (<20 km) among mite populations on either side of sub-Antarctic Marion Island (42) as well as among continental Antarctic populations of Fnesea propria and Friesea gretae (previously known as Friesea grisea; ref. 43) in northern Victoria Land (36), attributed to historical events and geographical barriers preventing dispersal.
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_location: Their long-term persistence in Antarctica would have necessitated survival in local refugia during glacial maxima followed by recolonization during more favorable interglacial periods (14).

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: Their long-term persistence in Antarctica would have necessitated survival in local refugia during glacial maxima followed by recolonization during more favorable interglacial periods (14).

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: Our genetic data corroborate climate reconstructions and estimates of past warm periods of reduced ice and absent ice shelf in the Ross Sea region, during which time open seaways would have facilitated dispersal of Collembola, and possibly other taxa.

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: For example, ancient and vicariant species of Antarctic Peninsula and Scotia Arc endemic midges have been separated for an estimated 49 My, since before the opening of the Drake Passage between South America and the South Shetland Islands 33 Mya to 30 Mya (21).

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_location: Here, we use the revised rate as a 2 of 10 | www.pnas.org/cgi/doi/10.1073/pnas.2007925117 more conservative estimate of divergence times for Antarctic Collembola of the Ross Sea region.

Sentence_location: While aerial transport for Cryptopygus antarcticus has been documented to occur at the Antarctic Peninsula (32), taxa in more arid environments, such as ice-free areas of the Ross Sea region, face a greater threat of desiccation while in transit (33).

Sentence_location: While aerial transport for Cryptopygus antarcticus has been documented to occur at the Antarctic Peninsula (32), taxa in more arid environments, such as ice-free areas of the Ross Sea region, face a greater threat of desiccation while in transit (33).

Sentence_location: Long-range dispersal of Collembola, particularly in the vicinity of the Ross Ice Shelf (Ross Sea region), would have only been possible with access to liquid water during periods of glacial retreat, as survival under shelf ice is extremely unlikely.

Sentence_location: Downloaded by guest on August 25, 2020 We assessed levels of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 (COI) sequence divergence for the six known species of Collembola found in southern Victoria Land (SVL), the Queen Alexandra Range (QAR), and the Queen Maud Mountains (QMM), within the Ross Sea region of continental Antarctica (Fig. 1).

Sentence_location: Downloaded by guest on August 25, 2020 We assessed levels of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 (COI) sequence divergence for the six known species of Collembola found in southern Victoria Land (SVL), the Queen Alexandra Range (QAR), and the Queen Maud Mountains (QMM), within the Ross Sea region of continental Antarctica (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_species: S@Se OO8SS ©O®@   C Tullbergia mediantarctica 83°S Latitude 85°S 170°E 175°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni                         B_Biscoia sudpolaris   (3 (11.7%)
Sentence_location: We suggest that these biological data provide evidence to corroborate hypothesized local geological/glaciological events and enhance our understanding of terrestrial and glaciological landscape evolution in Antarctica.

Sentence_location: During this time when conditions were warmer, multiple collapses of the WAIS likely occurred (45, 46), lasting for extended periods, and this would have drastically improved dispersal opportunities for Collembola in the Ross Sea region, facilitated by flotation along coastal margins.

Sentence_location: The finer-scale genetic variation in G. hodgsoni among the widespread coastal populations (<1.6% divergence) could further be attributed to the most recent warm events within the last 2 My, as has been considered for three species of Collembola from the South Shetland Islands (53).

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_species: Longitude 160°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni B Cryptopygus nivicolus
Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: Longitude 160°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni B Cryptopygus nivicolus
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: Longitude 160°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni B Cryptopygus nivicolus
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: Longitude 160°E A Gomphiocephalus hodgsoni B Cryptopygus nivicolus
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP258-13] 4 monoculata 0.04 a Cliff Nunatak/Mount Murray (North), SVL (23; 1) [ANTSP575-15] [s 527 | South Shackleton Glacier, QMM (30; 4) [ANTSP001-11] A. subpolaris : ~ PI Ta, 8.48 North Shackleton Glacier, QMM (4; 2)
Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP258-13] 4 monoculata 0.04 a Cliff Nunatak/Mount Murray (North), SVL (23; 1) [ANTSP575-15] [s 527 | South Shackleton Glacier, QMM (30; 4) [ANTSP001-11] A. subpolaris : ~ PI Ta, 8.48 North Shackleton Glacier, QMM (4; 2)
Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP258-13] 4 monoculata 0.04 a Cliff Nunatak/Mount Murray (North), SVL (23; 1) [ANTSP575-15] [s 527 | South Shackleton Glacier, QMM (30; 4) [ANTSP001-11] A. subpolaris : ~ PI Ta, 8.48 North Shackleton Glacier, QMM (4; 2)
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP258-13] 4 monoculata 0.04 a Cliff Nunatak/Mount Murray (North), SVL (23; 1) [ANTSP575-15] [s 527 | South Shackleton Glacier, QMM (30; 4) [ANTSP001-11] A. subpolaris : ~ PI Ta, 8.48 North Shackleton Glacier, QMM (4; 2)
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP258-13] 4 monoculata 0.04 a Cliff Nunatak/Mount Murray (North), SVL (23; 1) [ANTSP575-15] [s 527 | South Shackleton Glacier, QMM (30; 4) [ANTSP001-11] A. subpolaris : ~ PI Ta, 8.48 North Shackleton Glacier, QMM (4; 2)
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP258-13] 4 monoculata 0.04 a Cliff Nunatak/Mount Murray (North), SVL (23; 1) [ANTSP575-15] [s 527 | South Shackleton Glacier, QMM (30; 4) [ANTSP001-11] A. subpolaris : ~ PI Ta, 8.48 North Shackleton Glacier, QMM (4; 2)
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP258-13] 4 monoculata 0.04 a Cliff Nunatak/Mount Murray (North), SVL (23; 1) [ANTSP575-15] [s 527 | South Shackleton Glacier, QMM (30; 4) [ANTSP001-11] A. subpolaris : ~ PI Ta, 8.48 North Shackleton Glacier, QMM (4; 2)
Sentence_location: Their long-term persistence in Antarctica would have necessitated survival in local refugia during glacial maxima followed by recolonization during more favorable interglacial periods (14).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP258-13] 4 monoculata 0.04 a Cliff Nunatak/Mount Murray (North), SVL (23; 1) [ANTSP575-15] [s 527 | South Shackleton Glacier, QMM (30; 4) [ANTSP001-11] A. subpolaris : ~ PI Ta, 8.48 North Shackleton Glacier, QMM (4; 2)
Sentence_location: Our genetic data corroborate climate reconstructions and estimates of past warm periods of reduced ice and absent ice shelf in the Ross Sea region, during which time open seaways would have facilitated dispersal of Collembola, and possibly other taxa.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP258-13] 4 monoculata 0.04 a Cliff Nunatak/Mount Murray (North), SVL (23; 1) [ANTSP575-15] [s 527 | South Shackleton Glacier, QMM (30; 4) [ANTSP001-11] A. subpolaris : ~ PI Ta, 8.48 North Shackleton Glacier, QMM (4; 2)
Sentence_location: For example, ancient and vicariant species of Antarctic Peninsula and Scotia Arc endemic midges have been separated for an estimated 49 My, since before the opening of the Drake Passage between South America and the South Shetland Islands 33 Mya to 30 Mya (21).

Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Their long-term persistence in Antarctica would have necessitated survival in local refugia during glacial maxima followed by recolonization during more favorable interglacial periods (14).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Our genetic data corroborate climate reconstructions and estimates of past warm periods of reduced ice and absent ice shelf in the Ross Sea region, during which time open seaways would have facilitated dispersal of Collembola, and possibly other taxa.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: For example, ancient and vicariant species of Antarctic Peninsula and Scotia Arc endemic midges have been separated for an estimated 49 My, since before the opening of the Drake Passage between South America and the South Shetland Islands 33 Mya to 30 Mya (21).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Here, we use the revised rate as a 2 of 10 | www.pnas.org/cgi/doi/10.1073/pnas.2007925117 more conservative estimate of divergence times for Antarctic Collembola of the Ross Sea region.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: While aerial transport for Cryptopygus antarcticus has been documented to occur at the Antarctic Peninsula (32), taxa in more arid environments, such as ice-free areas of the Ross Sea region, face a greater threat of desiccation while in transit (33).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: While aerial transport for Cryptopygus antarcticus has been documented to occur at the Antarctic Peninsula (32), taxa in more arid environments, such as ice-free areas of the Ross Sea region, face a greater threat of desiccation while in transit (33).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Long-range dispersal of Collembola, particularly in the vicinity of the Ross Ice Shelf (Ross Sea region), would have only been possible with access to liquid water during periods of glacial retreat, as survival under shelf ice is extremely unlikely.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: Downloaded by guest on August 25, 2020 We assessed levels of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 (COI) sequence divergence for the six known species of Collembola found in southern Victoria Land (SVL), the Queen Alexandra Range (QAR), and the Queen Maud Mountains (QMM), within the Ross Sea region of continental Antarctica (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1362-18] C. nivicolus Springtail Point, SVL (11; 5)
Sentence_location: We suggest that these biological data provide evidence to corroborate hypothesized local geological/glaciological events and enhance our understanding of terrestrial and glaciological landscape evolution in Antarctica.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP570-15] Towle Glacier, SVL (2; 1) [ANTSP625-15] B. sudpolaris Beardmore Glacier, QAR-QMM (35; 5) [ANTSP1360-18] iain Beardmore Glacier, QAR (12; 1)
Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP570-15] Towle Glacier, SVL (2; 1) [ANTSP625-15] B. sudpolaris Beardmore Glacier, QAR-QMM (35; 5) [ANTSP1360-18] iain Beardmore Glacier, QAR (12; 1)
Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP570-15] Towle Glacier, SVL (2; 1) [ANTSP625-15] B. sudpolaris Beardmore Glacier, QAR-QMM (35; 5) [ANTSP1360-18] iain Beardmore Glacier, QAR (12; 1)
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP570-15] Towle Glacier, SVL (2; 1) [ANTSP625-15] B. sudpolaris Beardmore Glacier, QAR-QMM (35; 5) [ANTSP1360-18] iain Beardmore Glacier, QAR (12; 1)
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP570-15] Towle Glacier, SVL (2; 1) [ANTSP625-15] B. sudpolaris Beardmore Glacier, QAR-QMM (35; 5) [ANTSP1360-18] iain Beardmore Glacier, QAR (12; 1)
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP570-15] Towle Glacier, SVL (2; 1) [ANTSP625-15] B. sudpolaris Beardmore Glacier, QAR-QMM (35; 5) [ANTSP1360-18] iain Beardmore Glacier, QAR (12; 1)
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP570-15] Towle Glacier, SVL (2; 1) [ANTSP625-15] B. sudpolaris Beardmore Glacier, QAR-QMM (35; 5) [ANTSP1360-18] iain Beardmore Glacier, QAR (12; 1)
Sentence_location: Their long-term persistence in Antarctica would have necessitated survival in local refugia during glacial maxima followed by recolonization during more favorable interglacial periods (14).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP570-15] Towle Glacier, SVL (2; 1) [ANTSP625-15] B. sudpolaris Beardmore Glacier, QAR-QMM (35; 5) [ANTSP1360-18] iain Beardmore Glacier, QAR (12; 1)
Sentence_location: Our genetic data corroborate climate reconstructions and estimates of past warm periods of reduced ice and absent ice shelf in the Ross Sea region, during which time open seaways would have facilitated dispersal of Collembola, and possibly other taxa.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP570-15] Towle Glacier, SVL (2; 1) [ANTSP625-15] B. sudpolaris Beardmore Glacier, QAR-QMM (35; 5) [ANTSP1360-18] iain Beardmore Glacier, QAR (12; 1)
Sentence_location: For example, ancient and vicariant species of Antarctic Peninsula and Scotia Arc endemic midges have been separated for an estimated 49 My, since before the opening of the Drake Passage between South America and the South Shetland Islands 33 Mya to 30 Mya (21).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP570-15] Towle Glacier, SVL (2; 1) [ANTSP625-15] B. sudpolaris Beardmore Glacier, QAR-QMM (35; 5) [ANTSP1360-18] iain Beardmore Glacier, QAR (12; 1)
Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_location: Furthermore, based on biodiversity patterns and genetic assessments of marine taxa (bryozoans, gastropods, and bivalves), collapse of the WAIS likely connected the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea (near the Antarctic Peninsula) (22).

Sentence_location: While aerial transport for Cryptopygus antarcticus has been documented to occur at the Antarctic Peninsula (32), taxa in more arid environments, such as ice-free areas of the Ross Sea region, face a greater threat of desiccation while in transit (33).

Sentence_location: Long-range dispersal of Collembola, particularly in the vicinity of the Ross Ice Shelf (Ross Sea region), would have only been possible with access to liquid water during periods of glacial retreat, as survival under shelf ice is extremely unlikely.

Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_location: We suggest that these biological data provide evidence to corroborate hypothesized local geological/glaciological events and enhance our understanding of terrestrial and glaciological landscape evolution in Antarctica.

Sentence_location: For example, ancient and vicariant species of Antarctic Peninsula and Scotia Arc endemic midges have been separated for an estimated 49 My, since before the opening of the Drake Passage between South America and the South Shetland Islands 33 Mya to 30 Mya (21).

Sentence_location: By comparing these estimated divergence times to estimates of past glaciological events in this region (3, 4), we suggest that warm periods, with reduced ice and open water, within the last 5 My were at least partially responsible for the present-day patterns of Collembola diversity observed in the Ross Sea region of Antarctica.

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1071-18] Sminthurus viridis, China (1)
Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1071-18] Sminthurus viridis, China (1)
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1071-18] Sminthurus viridis, China (1)
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1071-18] Sminthurus viridis, China (1)
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_species: [ANTSP1071-18] Sminthurus viridis, China (1)

Sentence_location: Their long-term persistence in Antarctica would have necessitated survival in local refugia during glacial maxima followed by recolonization during more favorable interglacial periods (14).

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_location: As Collembola are a living record of past landscape evolution within Antarctica, these findings provide biological evidence to support geological and glaciological estimates of historical WAIS dynamics over the last ca.

Sentence_location: These warmer temperatures are thought to have caused a total collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and retreat of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) marine margins, as well as the Greenland Ice Sheet, resulting in an estimated 14-m rise in global mean sea level as compared to present-day levels (2-4).

Sentence_species: East 5.27 3.76 to 7.01 0.016 0.004 3.2 G. hodgsoni (4) 0.0153 0.005 3.06 SVL vs. QAR 3.52 2.56 to 4.64 Towle Gl. vs. All other SVL 2.78 2.00 to 3.66 Mt. Gran vs. | Widespread coastal 2.20 1.49 to 3.03 C. nivicolus (3) 0.0089 0.003 1.78
Sentence_location: Much of Antarctica’s terrestrial biodiversity, including microinvertebrates (mites, springtails, nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers), is concentrated along the Transantarctic Mountains where the WAIS and EAIS converge (Fig. 1).

Sentence_species: East 5.27 3.76 to 7.01 0.016 0.004 3.2 G. hodgsoni (4) 0.0153 0.005 3.06 SVL vs. QAR 3.52 2.56 to 4.64 Towle Gl. vs. All other SVL 2.78 2.00 to 3.66 Mt. Gran vs. | Widespread coastal 2.20 1.49 to 3.03 C. nivicolus (3) 0.0089 0.003 1.78
Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_species: East 5.27 3.76 to 7.01 0.016 0.004 3.2 G. hodgsoni (4) 0.0153 0.005 3.06 SVL vs. QAR 3.52 2.56 to 4.64 Towle Gl. vs. All other SVL 2.78 2.00 to 3.66 Mt. Gran vs. | Widespread coastal 2.20 1.49 to 3.03 C. nivicolus (3) 0.0089 0.003 1.78
Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_location: Among the largest terrestrial animals in Antarctica are the microarthropod Collembola (springtails) and Acari (mites), at generally <2 mm in length (10), as well as Diptera (flies/midges) from the Antarctic Peninsula.

Sentence_location: Their long-term persistence in Antarctica would have necessitated survival in local refugia during glacial maxima followed by recolonization during more favorable interglacial periods (14).

Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).

Sentence_location: Rather than latitude, local environmental factors (including those associated with elevation and distance from the coast), local microhabitats, historical glacial events, and geographic barriers have largely dictated the distribution and diversity of present-day biological communities in Antarctica (12, 13).
